definitions.definition: A moving disturbance in the level of a body of liquid ; an undulation .
examples: The wave traveled from the center of the lake before breaking on the shore.

definitions.definition: A moving disturbance in the energy level of a field .
examples: Gravity waves , while predicted by theory for decades, have been notoriously difficult to detect.

definitions.definition: A shape that alternatingly curves in opposite directions.
examples: Her hair had a nice wave to it.

definitions.definition: Any of a number of species of moths in the geometrid subfamily Sterrhinae , which have wavy markings on the wings.
A loose back-and-forth movement, as of the hands.
examples: He dismissed her with a wave of the hand.

definitions.definition: A sudden, but temporary, uptick in something.
examples: A wave of shoppers stampeded through the door when the store opened for its Christmas discount special.
A wave of retirees began moving to the coastal area.
A wave of emotion overcame her when she thought about her son who was killed in battle.

definitions.definition: A movement or trend in popular culture .
One of the successive swarms of enemies sent to attack the player in certain games.
A group activity in a crowd imitating a wave going through water, where people in successive parts of the crowd stand and stretch upward, then sit.

main_definition: A moving disturbance in the level of a body of liquid ; an undulation .
secondary_definitions: ( physics ) A moving disturbance in the energy level of a field .
A shape that alternatingly curves in opposite directions.
Any of a number of species of moths in the geometrid subfamily Sterrhinae , which have wavy markings on the wings.
A loose back-and-forth movement, as of the hands.
( figurative ) A sudden, but temporary, uptick in something.
( figurative ) A movement or trend in popular culture .
( video games , by extension ) One of the successive swarms of enemies sent to attack the player in certain games.
( usually "the wave" ) A group activity in a crowd imitating a wave going through water, where people in successive parts of the crowd stand and stretch upward, then sit.
